Literature Review: The structure and role of O-linked glycans in viral envelope proteins have been the subject of extensive research due to their significant impact on viral biology and host-pathogen interactions. O-linked glycosylation, a post-translational modification, is initiated by a family of 20 human polypeptide O-acetylgalactosaminyl transferases, leading to a diverse array of O-glycan structures. This heterogeneity is crucial for the functional versatility of O-glycans in viral envelope proteins (Brockhausen et al., 2009). O-glycans can exist as solitary units or form clusters known as mucin-like domains, which are particularly prevalent in viral envelope proteins and play pivotal roles in the viral life cycle and host colonization (Varki et al., 2017). The presence of negatively charged O-glycans, such as those modified with heparan sulfate or chondroitin sulfate, is essential for the interaction between glycosaminoglycan-binding viruses and their host cells. These interactions are critical for viral attachment and entry into host cells (Aquino & Park, 2016). A novel mechanism involving controlled electrostatic repulsion has been proposed to explain how viruses balance the need for efficient attachment to target cells with the requirement for the effective release of progeny virions. This mechanism highlights the sophisticated strategies employed by viruses to optimize their life cycle (Watanabe et al., 2019). Conserved solitary O-glycans have been identified as important factors in the viral uptake process, particularly in facilitating the fusion of the viral envelope with host cell membranes. This process is crucial for the successful infection of target cells (Bagdonaite et al., 2018). Furthermore, O-glycans play dual roles in the host B cell immune response. They can either block or promote the formation of epitopes, influencing the immune system's ability to recognize and respond to viral infections. This dual functionality presents opportunities for the development of novel vaccine strategies that exploit the immunomodulatory properties of O-glycans (Hansen et al., 2018). Additionally, specific virus-induced O-glycans have been implicated in the viremic spread of viruses, suggesting that these glycans may be key factors in the systemic dissemination of viral infections (Cohen et al., 2017). The exploration of O-glycan functions in viral envelope proteins continues to uncover new insights into viral pathogenesis and host immune responses, offering potential avenues for therapeutic intervention and vaccine development.
